- Arrays with lots of access methods

- Arrays as just above
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Data-LnArray-XS

- https://metacpan.org/dist/HATX

o List::MoreUtils:
- Provide the stuff missing in List::Util
- https://metacpan.org/pod/List::MoreUtils

o List::Util:
- This is a core module
- Note: List::Util::XS is available
- use List::Util 'any' or, better, 'first' (but don't use first() for finding 0 or undef!)
- And then 1 of:
- if(any { $_ eq $thing } @values) ...
- if(any { $_ == $thing } @values) ...
- It's not limited to just string or number comparison of course; you can
put any arbitrary code in there. if(any { $_->is_close_to(123.45) } @values) ...
- Or
- If you don't like the XSUB call overhead of List::Util::any, there's
another (non-core) CPAN module List::Keywords which implements many of
the same utilities as real keywords with real opcodes, so they run
faster.
- use List::Keywords 'any';
- if(any { $_ eq $thing } @values) ...
- Or
- if (grep { $_ eq $myval } @arr)

o List::UtilsBy:
- Higher-order list utility functions
- https://metacpan.org/pod/List::UtilsBy
- Amazing!

o Math::MatrixBool:

- https://metacpan.org/pod/Syntax::Operator::Zip
- Provides 2 functions: mesh and zip, both of which are in List::Util
- Also, List::UtilsBy contains zip_by and unzip_by

text:
""" o The docs here were copied from Google's Gemini, when I asked it how to generate a cpanfile o CPAN::Audit: - Audit CPAN distributions for known vulnerabilities - https://metacpan.org/dist/CPAN-Audit - This module contains cpan-audit, which uses a cpanfile or a cpanfile.snapshot file o Docs: 
**1. Manual Creation**

* **Create a file named `cpanfile`:** This file will reside in the root directory of your project.
* **Add dependencies:**
    * Each line in the `cpanfile` represents a dependency.
    * Use the following syntax: `require 'ModuleName';`
    * Example:
      ```perl
        require 'JSON';
        require 'Template';
        require 'DateTime';
        require 'DBIx::Class';
        `

**2. Using `Mojolicious::Command::Author::generate::cpanfile`**

* **Install the Mojolicious framework (if not already installed):**
    ```bash
    cpanm Mojolicious
    ```
* **Generate the `cpanfile`:**
    ```bash
    mojo generate cpanfile
    ```
    This command analyzes your Perl source code files (usually located in the `lib` directory) to identify used modules and generates the `cpanfile` accordingly.

**3. Using Carton**

* **Install Carton:**
    ```bash
    cpanm Carton
    ```
* **Create a `cpanfile`:**
    ```bash
    carton init
    ```
    This creates a basic `cpanfile` with some default settings. You can then manually add your project's specific dependencies.

**Key Considerations**

* **Version Constraints:** You can specify version constraints for your dependencies to ensure compatibility and stability. For example:
    ```perl
    require 'Module::Name' => '>= 1.2.3';
    ```
* **Local Modules:** If you have local modules that are not on CPAN, you can add them to your `cpanfile` using special directives.
* **Testing:** After generating your `cpanfile`, always test your application to ensure all dependencies are installed correctly and your application functions as expected.

**Example `cpanfile`**

```perl
require 'JSON';
require 'Template' => '>= 2.18';
require 'DateTime';
require 'DBIx::Class';
require 'MyLocalModule'; # A hypothetical local module
```

By using a `cpanfile`, you can easily manage and install the necessary dependencies for your Perl projects, making your development process more efficient and reproducible.
title: CpanFile

If you're intending to encrypt larger blocks or entire files, please use Crypt::CBC in conjunction with this module o Crypt::DES_EDE3: - Triple-DES EDE encryption/decryption - https://metacpan.org/dist/Crypt-DES_EDE3 - This is a wrapper around Crypt::DES o Crypt::Diceware: - Random passphrase generator loosely based on the Diceware algorithm - https://metacpan.org/pod/Crypt::Diceware o Crypt::DSA: - DSA Signatures and Key Generation - Crypt::DSA is an implementation of the DSA (Digital Signature Algorithm) signature verification system - The heavy-duty mathematics underneath are provided by the Math::Pari library - DSA (Digital Signature Algorithm) signatures are no longer considered to be adequate for security o Crypt::Fernet: - Perl extension for Fernet (symmetric encryption) - https://metacpan.org/dist/Crypt-Fernet o Crypt::HSM - A PKCS11 interface for Perl - https://metacpan.org/dist/Crypt-HSM o Crypt::JWT: - JSON Web Token (JWT, JWS, JWE) as defined by RFC7519, RFC7515, RFC7516 - https://metacpan.org/pod/Crypt::JWT o Crypt::Komihash: - Komihash implementation in Perl - https://metacpan.org/pod/Crypt::Komihash o Crypt::MatrixSSL3: - Perl extension for SSL and TLS using MatrixSSL.org v3.9.3 - https://metacpan.org/dist/Crypt-MatrixSSL3 o Crypt::OpenSSL::AES: - https://metacpan.org/pod/Crypt::OpenSSL::AES - A Perl wrapper around OpenSSL's AES library - See also Crypt::CBC o Crypt::OpenSSL::PKCS12 - Perl extension to OpenSSL's PKCS12 API - https://metacpan.org/dist/Crypt-OpenSSL-PKCS12 o Crypt::OpenSSL::RSA: - RSA encoding and decoding, using the openSSL libraries - https://metacpan.org/dist/Crypt-OpenSSL-RSA o Crypt::OpenSSL::BaseFunc: - Base Functions, using the OpenSSL libraries - https://metacpan.org/dist/Crypt-OpenSSL-BaseFunc o Crypt::Passphrase: - Crypt::Passphrase::Argon2::AES (See below for Crypt::Argon) - Crypt::Passphrase::Bcrypt::AES. Uses Kubernetes, so must be pathologically complex - Mojolicious::Plugin::Credentials o Crypt::Perl: - Cryptography in pure Perl - https://metacpan.org/dist/Crypt-Perl - Can create and sign in X509 in pure Perl. Slow without the XS addons o Crypt::PostgreSQL: - Module for generating encrypted password for PostgreSQL - https://metacpan.org/dist/Crypt-PostgreSQL o Crypt::Protocol: - No POD - https://metacpan.org/dist/Crypt-Protocol o Crypt::Random::Source: - Get weak or strong random data from pluggable sources - https://metacpan.org/dist/Crypt-Random-Source o Crypt::Rhash: - Compute message digests and magnet links - https://metacpan.org/pod/Crypt::Rhash o Crypt::RSA::Blind: - Blind RSA signatures - https://metacpan.org/dist/Crypt-RSA-Blind o Crypt::SecretBuffer: - Prevent accidentally leaking a string of sensitive data - https://metacpan.org/pod/Crypt::SecretBuffer o Crypt::SMIME: - S/MIME message signing, verification, encryption and decryption - https://metacpan.org/dist/Crypt-SMIME o Crypt::Sodium::XS: - Perl XS bindings for libsodium - https://metacpan.org/dist/Crypt-Sodium-XS - https://doc.libsodium.org/ o Crypt::SysRandom: - Perl interface to system randomness - https://metacpan.org/dist/Crypt-SysRandom o Crypt::SysRandom::XS: - Perl interface to system randomness, XS version - https://metacpan.org/dist/Crypt-SysRandom-XS o Crypt::URandom - Provide non blocking randomness - https://metacpan.org/pod/Crypt::URandom - This is a pure-Perl module that reads data from /dev/urandom. It also uses Win32::API to read random bytes on Windows o Crypt::URandom::MonkeyPatch: - Override core rand function to use system random sources Deprecated o Crypt::URandom::Token: - Generate secure strings for passwords, secrets and similar - https://metacpan.org/pod/Crypt::URandom::Token o Crypt::Yescrypt: - A Perl interface to the yescrypt password hash - https://metacpan.org/dist/Crypt-Yescrypt o CryptX: - This is a huge crypto toolkit - Bytes::Random::Secure::Tiny - Crypt::Passphrase::*. Included timeout/refresh help - Crypt::PRNG::ChaCha20 - Cryptographically secure PRNG based on ChaCha20 (stream cipher) algorithm. Used in UUID - Random numbers: CryptX::PrNG::Fortuna - App::xsum o Data::Entropy: - Entropy (randomness) management - https://metacpan.org/dist/Data-Entropy - Deprecated o Digest::HMAC: - Keyed-Hashing for Message Authentication - https://metacpan.org/dist/Digest-HMAC o Digest::SHA3: - Prefer this to Digest::SHA o Digests: - Digest::BLAKE2 - Message digest algorithm (which is an excellent security improvement: Bruce Scheiner) - Digest::MD5 - Alt::Digest::MD5::OpenSSL - https://metacpan.org/pod/Alt::Digest::MD5::OpenSSL o Filter::Crypto: - Create runnable Perl files encrypted with OpenSSL libcrypto - https://metacpan.org/dist/Filter-Crypto o Filter::Crypto::Decrypt: - Perl source code filter to run encrypted Perl files - https://metacpan.org/pod/Filter::Crypto::Decrypt o libcrypto: - See http://www.openssl.org o Math::Random::Secure: - Cryptographically-secure, cross-platform replacement for rand() - https://metacpan.org/dist/Math-Random-Secure o Random::Any: - Try to use Data::Entropy::Algorithms::rand(), fallback on builtin rand() - https://metacpan.org/dist/Random-Any o Random::Simple: - Simple, usable, real world random numbers - https://metacpan.org/dist/Random-Simple o Rand::URandom - Replaces rand() with /dev/urandom - https://metacpan.org/dist/Rand-Urandom - This is a pure-Perl module that makes syscalls to getrandom(2), but falls back to reading from /dev/urandom o Sys::GetRandom - Perl interface to getrandom(2) - This is an XS module that calls getrandom(2) directly. It has a slightly different interface but is faster - https://metacpan.org/pod/Sys::GetRandom o Sys::GetRandom::PP: - Pure Perl interface to getrandom(2) - https://metacpan.org/dist/Sys-GetRandom-PP

text:
""" o See also: - ConfigFiles - FileHandling - UsernamePassword o Note: GraphViz2::DBI ships with db.schema.pl, which creates an SVG image of a schema: - To run it you need to set three environment variables as below - dbi.schema.pl takes an option parameter of image type, which defaults to svg - Edit the code if you wish to change the output dir's name - The last line, the copy, is for my setup. $DR points to a RAM disk. Debian automatically creates a RAM disk, so I configure the free web server Engine X, aka nginx, to use it. See my other TiddlyWiki, Debian.Wiki.html, for details about nginx - And yes, you can use empty strings for the username and password - Lastly, $ is just the command line prompt 
$ DBI_DSN=dbi:SQLite:dbname=data/levies.sqlite
$ DBI_USER=local
$ DBI_PASS=local
$ export DBI_DSN DBI_USER DBI_PASS
$ mkdir html
$ dbi.schema.pl (my version)
$ cp html/dbi.schema.svg $DR/levy.schema.svg
o Alien::DuckDB: - Find or build DuckDB - https://metacpan.org/dist/Alien-DuckDB o AnyEvent::Redis: - Non-blocking Redis client - https://metacpan.org/pod/AnyEvent::Redis o App::DBBrowser: - Browse SQLite/MySQL/PostgreSQL databases and their tables interactively - https://metacpan.org/dist/App-DBBrowser o App::Sqitch: - Sensible database change management - Sqitch is a database change management application - https://metacpan.org/dist/App-Sqitch - http://sqitch.org/ o App::SQLiteUtils o App::dbitemplater: - A utility for running a SQL query via DBI and using the output in a template - https://metacpan.org/dist/App-dbitemplater o BerkeleyDB: - Perl extension for Berkeley DB version 2, 3, 4, 5 or 6 - https://metacpan.org/dist/BerkeleyDB o Catmandu::DBI: - Catmandu tools to communicate with DBI based interfaces - https://metacpan.org/pod/Catmandu::DBI - This is (presumably) unrelated to Catmandu in DataTraversal o Couch::DB: - CouchDB database client - https://metacpan.org/dist/Couch-DB o CXC::DB::DDL: - DDL for table creation, based on SQL::Translator::Schema - https://metacpan.org/dist/CXC-DB-DDL o Data::ObjectDriver: - Simple, transparent data interface, with caching - https://metacpan.org/dist/Data-ObjectDriver o Data::Record::Serialize: - https://metacpan.org/pod/Data::Record::Serialize - Flexible serialization of a record - A module which encodes data in various ways and can further transmit the result - This module is primarily useful for output of sets of uniformly structured data records. It provides a uniform, thin, interface to various serializers and output sinks. Its raison d'etre is its ability to manipulate the records prior to encoding and output o Data::SimpleKV: - A simple key-value database with memory cache and disk persistence - https://metacpan.org/dist/Data-SimpleKV o Data::TagDB - Work with Tag databases - https://metacpan.org/dist/Data-TagDB - See also File::FStore in FileHandling o Data::TagDB::Tag: - Work with Tag databases - https://metacpan.org/pod/Data::TagDB::Tag o Database - various: - App::dbinfo - Data::ObjectDriver - https://metacpan.org/pod/Data::ObjectDriver - DBIx::Simple[::Concrete, Interpol] - DBIx::Placeholder::Named - PGObject::Util::DBAdmin - DBIx::Raw - DBIx::Connector::Retry[::MySQL] o Database which auto-removes itself after use: - Database::Temp o Database::Abstraction: - Database abstraction layer - https://metacpan.org/pod/Database::Abstraction - Abstract class giving read-only access to CSV, XML and SQLite databases via Perl without writing any SQL o Database::ManagedHandle: - Manage database handles safely for long running processes - https://metacpan.org/pod/Database::ManagedHandle o DB::Berkeley: - XS-based OO Berkeley DB HASH interface - https://metacpan.org/dist/DB-Berkeley o DB::Object: - SQL API - By Jacques Deguest - https://metacpan.org/pod/DB::Object o DB_File: - Perl5 access to Berkeley DB version 1.x - https://metacpan.org/pod/DB_File o DBD::AnyData: - DBI access to XML, CSV and other formats - Awating DBD::AnyData2 o DBD::Firebird: - DBI driver for Firebird RDBMS server - https://metacpan.org/dist/DBD-Firebird o DBD::KB: - Kingbase database driver for the DBI module - https://metacpan.org/dist/DBD-KB o DBD::Oracle: - Oracle database driver for the DBI module - https://metacpan.org/pod/DBD::Oracle o DBD::Pg: - PostgreSQL database driver for the DBI module - https://metacpan.org/dist/DBD-Pg o DBD::PgAsync: - A PostgreSQL database driver for the DBI module - https://metacpan.org/dist/DBD-PgAsync o DBD::Sybase: - Sybase database driver for the DBI module - https://metacpan.org/dist/DBD-Sybase o DBD::XMLSimple: - Access XML data via the DBI interface - https://metacpan.org/dist/DBD-XMLSimple o DBIx::Admin::TableInfo: - A wrapper for all of table_info(), column_info(), *_key_info() - https://metacpan.org/dist/DBIx-Admin-TableInfo o DBIx::AutoUpgrade::NativeStrings: - https://metacpan.org/pod/DBIx::AutoUpgrade::NativeStrings - Automatically upgrade Perl native strings to utf8 before sending them to the database - Primarily for DBD::Oracle, DPD::Pg and DBD::SQLite o DBIx::BatchChunker: - Run large database changes safely - For DML - https://metacpan.org/pod/DBIx::BatchChunker - See also DBIx::BulkLoader::Mysql, DBIx::Class::BatchUpdate, DBIx::BulkUtil - See also DBIx::OnlineDDL below for DDL o DBIx::Class: - Why are there no details for this module? - Because it is effectively dead. Who says? - See DBIx::QuickORM as a similar alternative, where the docs discuss and criticize DBIx::Class - Or consider simple alternatives like DBIx::Simple or DBIx::Squirrel - Or see the great article on DBIx::Class::Result::PrettyPrint at https://peateasea.de/introducing-dbix-class-resultset-prettyprint/ o DBIx::Class::EncodedColumn: - Automatically encode columns - https://metacpan.org/dist/DBIx-Class-EncodedColumn o DBIx::Class::Helpers: - Simplify the common case stuff for DBIx::Class - https://metacpan.org/dist/DBIx-Class-Helpers o DBIx::Class::Helper::ColumnNames: - Retrieve column names from a resultset - https://metacpan.org/dist/DBIx-Class-Helper-ColumnNames o DBIx::Class::Schema: - Composable schemas - https://metacpan.org/pod/DBIx::Class::Schema o DBIx::Class::Schema::Loader: - Create a DBIx::Class::Schema based on a database - https://metacpan.org/dist/DBIx-Class-Schema-Loader o DBIx::Connector: - Fast, safe DBI connection and transaction management - https://metacpan.org/dist/DBIx-Connector o DBIx::Custom: - DBI extension to execute insert, update, delete, and select easily - It extends Object::Simple - https://metacpan.org/pod/DBIx::Custom o DBIx::DataModel: - UML-based Object-Relational Mapping (ORM) framework - https://metacpan.org/pod/DBIx::DataModel o DBIx::Diff::Schema: - Compare schema of two DBI databases - https://metacpan.org/pod/DBIx::Diff::Schema o DBIx::Fast: - DBI fast & easy (another one...) - https://metacpan.org/pod/DBIx::Fast o DBIx::Lite: - Chained and minimal ORM - https://metacpan.org/pod/DBIx::Lite - This module tries very hard to do a lot of work for you o DBIx::Migration: - Seamless DB schema up- and downgrades - https://metacpan.org/dist/DBIx-Migration o DBIx::DBO: - An OO interface to SQL queries and results - Easily constructs SQL queries, and simplifies processing of the returned data - https://metacpan.org/dist/DBIx-DBO o DBIx::OnlineDDL: - Run DDL on online databases safely - See also gh-ost - See also https://docs.percona.com/percona-toolkit/pt-online-schema-change.html - See also https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.4/en/innodb-online-ddl.html o DBIx::Query: - Simplified abstracted chained DBI subclass - A subclass of DBI - https://metacpan.org/dist/DBIx-Query - Can use Perl data structures described by SQL::Abstract::Complete o DBIx::QuickDB: - Quickly start a db server - https://metacpan.org/pod/DBIx::QuickDB - PostgreSQL and MySQL are the initially supported drivers o DBIx::QuickORM: - Actively maintained Object Relational Mapping that makes getting started Quick and has a rich feature set - An alternative to DBIx::Class, but not a drop-in replacement. - https://metacpan.org/dist/DBIx-QuickORM o DBIx::SearchBuilder: - Encapsulate SQL queries and rows in simple Perl objects o DBIx::Squirrel: - A DBI extension - https://metacpan.org/pod/DBIx::Squirrel - The DBIx::Squirrel package extends the DBI by providing a few extra conveniences that are subtle and additive in nature, and, hopefully, quite useful - Looks good o DBIx::Sunny: - https://metacpan.org/pod/DBIx::Sunny - DBIx::Sunny is a simple DBI wrapper. It provides better usability for you - DBIx::Sunny supports only SQLite and MySQL - Supports nested transaction management using DBIx::TransactionManager - See also SQL::Maker::SQLType - https://metacpan.org/pod/SQL::Maker::SQLType o DiaColloDB: - Diachronic collocation database, top-level - https://metacpan.org/dist/DiaColloDB o Fey: - Better SQL Generation Through Perl - https://metacpan.org/dist/Fey o Fey::ORM: - A Fey-based ORM - https://metacpan.org/dist/Fey-ORM o gh-ost: - Is a triggerless online schema migration solution for MySQL - https://github.com/github/gh-ost o GraphViz2::DBI: - Visualize a database schema as a graph - https://metacpan.org/pod/GraphViz2::DBI - Uses DBIx::Admin::TableInfo o LMDB_File: - Tie to LMDB (OpenLDAP's Lightning Memory-Mapped Database) - https://metacpan.org/dist/LMDB_File o Mojo::Redis: - Redis driver based on Mojo::IOLoop - https://metacpan.org/pod/Mojo::Redis o MongoDB: - Official MongoDB Driver for Perl (EOL) - https://metacpan.org/pod/MongoDB - End of life: August 13, 2020 o MySQL-specific: - DateTime::Format::MySQL o MySQL::Hi: - Credentials for MySQL/MariaDB from config files - https://metacpan.org/pod/MySQL::Hi o Neo4j::Driver: - Neo4j community graph database driver for Bolt and HTTP - https://metacpan.org/dist/Neo4j-Driver o Paws::DynamoDB::Response::Parser: - Convert Paws DynamoDB response objects to Perl data structures - https://metacpan.org/pod/Paws::DynamoDB::Response::Parser o Pg::Explain: - Object approach at reading explain analyze output - https://metacpan.org/dist/Pg-Explain o PGXN::Site: - Maintain and serve a PGXN web site for talking to Postgres - https://metacpan.org/pod/PGXN::Site o Pongo: - A Perl MongoDB interface using XS and the MongoDB C driver - https://metacpan.org/dist/Pongo o Protocol::Redis: - Redis protocol parser/encoder with asynchronous capabilities. - https://metacpan.org/pod/Protocol::Redis o Protocol::Redis::XS: - hiredis based parser compatible with Protocol::Redis - https://metacpan.org/pod/Protocol::Redis::XS o Redis: - Perl binding for Redis database - https://metacpan.org/pod/Redis o Redis::hiredis: - Interact with Redis using the hiredis client - https://metacpan.org/pod/Redis::hiredis o Rose::DB::Object: - Extensible, high performance object-relational mapper (ORM) - Contains Rose::DB::Object::Tutorial - A guided tour of the basics of Rose::DB::Object - https://metacpan.org/dist/Rose-DB-Object - See also https://dev.to/dragostrif/rosedb-orm-and-perl-3dig o SQL::Inserter: - Efficient buffered DBI inserter and fast INSERT SQL builder o SQL: - SQL::Abstract - SQL::Abstract::Complete - Generate complete SQL from Perl data structures - SQL::Abstract::More - Uses the above. Looks good. Related to DBIx::DataModel - https://metacpan.org/pod/SQL::Abstract::More - DBI::Abstract o SQL::Abstract::ExtraClauses: - New/experimental additions to SQL::Abstract - https://metacpan.org/pod/SQL::Abstract::Plugin::ExtraClauses o SQL::Abstract::Plugin::TableAlias: - Automagical table aliasing - https://metacpan.org/dist/SQL-Abstract-Plugin-TableAlias - This module is an extension of the SQL::Abstract::Plugin::ExtraClauses plugin o SQL::Interp: - Interpolate Perl variables into SQL statements - https://metacpan.org/dist/SQL-Interp - Includes DBIx::Interp - POD discusses Class::DBI, DBIx::Simple, FU::SQL, SQL::Abstract, SQL::Interpol, SQL::KeywordSearch, SQL::Preproc and SQL::String o SQL::Parser: - Validate and parse SQL strings - https://metacpan.org/pod/SQL::Parser - This module is part of SQL::Statement - https://metacpan.org/dist/SQL-Statement o SQL::Translator: - Manipulate structured data definitions (SQL and more) - https://metacpan.org/dist/SQL-Translator o TDB_FileX: - Perl access to the trivial database library - https://metacpan.org/pod/TDB_FileX o TheSchwartz ecosystem: - A reliable job queue - TheSchwartz::Simple - Lightweight TheSchwartz job dispatcher using plain DBI - TheSchwartz::JobScheduler - Lightweight TheSchwartz job dispatcher with maintained database connections

""" o See also: - JsonStuff o JE: - Pure-Perl ECMAScript (JavaScript) Engine - https://metacpan.org/dist/JE o JavaScript::Duktape: - Perl interface to Duktape embeddable javascript engine - https://metacpan.org/pod/JavaScript::Duktape - See also https://duktape.org/api.html and https://duktape.org/guide o JavaScript::Packer: - Perl version of Dean Edwards' Packer.js - https://metacpan.org/dist/JavaScript-Packer o JavaScript::QuickJS: - Run JavaScript via QuickJS in Perl - https://metacpan.org/dist/JavaScript-QuickJS o JavaScript::V8::XS: - Perl XS binding for the V8 Javascript embeddable engine - https://metacpan.org/pod/JavaScript::V8::XS o JQ::Lite: - A lightweight jq-like JSON query engine in Perl - https://metacpan.org/dist/JQ-Lite - Sample code: 
#/usr/bin/env perl

use JQ::Lite;

my $json = '{"users":[{"name":"Alice"},{"name":"Bob"}]}';
my $jq = JQ::Lite->new;
my @names = $jq->run_query($json, '.users[].name');
print join("\n", @names), "\n";

text:
""" o See also: - CryptoStuff - JavaScript - https://www.json.org/json-en.html - https://jsonlines.org/ - https://json-schema.org - https://json-schema.org/understanding-json-schema/reference - CSS.and.Javascript.html which mentions jq and JSON::JQ - https://www.relaxedjson.org/specification o CBOR::XS: - Concise Binary Object Representation (CBOR, RFC7049) - https://metacpan.org/dist/CBOR-XS o Cpanel::JSON::XS: - Recommended despite the old comments below - Marc Lehmann has (long ago?) said bad things about this module. See the POD for JSON::SIMD, under Interoperability as above - It can be necessary. See ~/bin/test.cpanel.json.xs.type.pl - Code: 
#! /usr/bin/perl
use warnings;
use strict;

use Cpanel::JSON::XS qw{ encode_json };
use Cpanel::JSON::XS::Type;

my $struct = {Parts => [{PartNumber => "1",
                         ETag => "46f438ba2afd8d6dc03958b867a349b1"},
                        {ETag => "7b1e03e9ed7bb49d907e5a2d25b89159",
                         PartNumber => "2"},
                        {ETag => "30c23faad792c9b7c4b05356305cb6b0",
                         PartNumber => "3"},
                        {ETag => "979174e5353386a75d8e36d223d22ea2",
                         PartNumber => "4"},
                        {PartNumber => "5",
                         ETag => "ee93774d0a2ec9c27fae6a4fb3496804"},
                        {PartNumber => "6",
                         ETag => "9a2c5a1abe6869f370b07d76c270e569"}
             ]};
print encode_json($struct,
                  {Parts => json_type_arrayof({
                      PartNumber => JSON_TYPE_INT,
                      ETag       => JSON_TYPE_STRING})});

Output:
{"Parts":[{"ETag":"46f438ba2afd8d6dc03958b867a349b1","PartNumber":1},
{"ETag":"7b1e03e9ed7bb49d907e5a2d25b89159","PartNumber":2},
{"ETag":"30c23faad792c9b7c4b05356305cb6b0","PartNumber":3},
{"PartNumber":4,"ETag":"979174e5353386a75d8e36d223d22ea2"},
{"PartNumber":5,"ETag":"ee93774d0a2ec9c27fae6a4fb3496804"},
{"PartNumber":6,"ETag":"9a2c5a1abe6869f370b07d76c270e569"}]}
o JSON::Lines: - Parse JSONLines with perl - https://metacpan.org/pod/JSON::Lines o JSON::MaybeXS: - Use Cpanel::JSON::XS with a fallback to JSON::XS and JSON::PP - https://metacpan.org/pod/JSON::MaybeXS o JSON::Path: - Implements JSONPath, an XPath-like language for searching JSON-like structures - https://metacpan.org/dist/JSON-Path - JSONPath is described at http://goessner.net/articles/JsonPath/ o JSON::PP: - JSON::XS compatible pure-Perl module - https://metacpan.org/dist/JSON-PP o JSON::Relaxed: - An extension of JSON that allows for better human-readability - https://metacpan.org/pod/JSON::Relaxed o JSON::Schema::Generate: - Generate JSON Schemas from data! - https://metacpan.org/dist/JSON-Schema-Generate o JSON::Schema::Modern: - Validate data against a schema using a JSON Schema - https://metacpan.org/dist/JSON-Schema-Modern o JSON::Schema::Tiny: - Validate data against a schema, minimally - https://metacpan.org/dist/JSON-Schema-Tiny o JSON::SIMD: - JSON serialising/deserialising, done correctly and faster - https://metacpan.org/dist/JSON-SIMD o JSON::ToHTML: - Render JSON-based Perl datastructures as HTML tables - https://metacpan.org/dist/JSON-ToHTML o JSON::Typist: - Replace mushy strings and numbers with rigidly typed replacements - https://metacpan.org/pod/JSON::Typist o JSON::XS: - JSON serialising/deserialising, done correctly and fast - https://metacpan.org/dist/JSON-XS o JSONL::Subset: - Extract a percentage of lines from a JSONL file - https://metacpan.org/dist/JSONL-Subset o OpenAPI::Modern: - Validate HTTP requests and responses against an OpenAPI v3.1 document - https://metacpan.org/dist/OpenAPI-Modern - Contains JSON::Schema::Modern::Document::OpenAPI and JSON::Schema::Modern::Vocabulary::OpenAPI

""" o Adobe PDF reference: - https://opensource.adobe.com/dc-acrobat-sdk-docs/pdfstandards/pdfreference1.7old.pdf - Versions of PDF are 1.0, 1.1, 1.2, 1.3, 1.4, 1.5, 1.6, 1.7 and now 2.0. There was never a public release using version number 1.06 (from an email from Deven T. Corzine) o Alien::PDFio: - Alien distribution for PDFio - https://metacpan.org/dist/Alien-PDFio - See PDFio::FFI below o App::DiffPDFText: - Diff the text of two PDF documents o App::Mxpress::PDF: - A utility application for generating PDFs - https://metacpan.org/dist/App-Mxpress-PDF o App::paperback: - Copy and transform pages from a PDF into a new PDF - https://metacpan.org/pod/App::paperback o App::pdfresize: - Resize each page of PDF file to a new dimension o App::PDFUtils: - Command-line utilities related to PDF files - https://metacpan.org/dist/App-PDFUtils - Ships with 10 utilities o CAM::PDF: - This package reads and writes any document that conforms to the PDF o CtrlO::PDF: - High level PDF creator - https://metacpan.org/dist/CtrlO-PDF o qpdf: - https://qpdf.sourceforge.io/ - Here is the Git repository for qpdf: https://github.com/qpdf/qpdf - Documentation for qpdf is here: https://qpdf.readthedocs.io/en/stable/ - Debian-specific notes follow. I'm using bookworm - libqpdf29 is installed by default for some reason - qpdf and qpdfview and libqpdf-dev can be installed with apt-get - qpfdview is a very convenient multi-doc (tabbed) viewer - Sample code, given x.pdf is say in v 1.6 format s output by LibreOffice: - qpdf --force-version=1.4 x.pdf x-1.4.pdf o Google Bard says: 
Command-line options:

    DiffPDF: Lightweight and simple, free and open-source. Compares text and images, highlights differences, can exclude margins and generate reports. However, lacks advanced features like layout or visual side-by-side comparison.
    Wdiff: Text-based diff tool, often installed by default. Good for textual comparisons, but not suitable for visual layout differences.

Graphical diff tools:

    Kompare: Powerful diff and merge tool for various file types, including PDFs. Supports side-by-side comparison, highlights differences, visual and textual comparisons. Has a steeper learning curve compared to simpler tools.
    Meld: Another popular diff and merge tool with side-by-side comparison, advanced filtering options, and support for directory comparisons.
    Diffuse: Lightweight GUI diff tool specifically for PDFs. Focuses on visual comparison with side-by-side view and highlighting. Lacks advanced features of some other tools.

Commercial options:

    Beyond Compare: Feature-rich diff and merge tool for various file types, including PDFs. Advanced comparison modes, visual and textual differences, filtering options, report generation, etc. Paid software.
    DiffMerge: Cross-platform diff tool with a GUI and powerful comparison engine for files and directories. Supports PDF comparison with side-by-side view, text alignment, and highlighting. Paid software.

Web-based options:

    Copyleaks: Online plagiarism checker that can compare PDFs and highlight text differences. Supports multiple languages. Free trial available, then paid subscription.

Here are some additional factors to consider when choosing a PDF comparison tool:

    Complexity of PDFs: For simple PDFs with just text, basic tools like DiffPDF might suffice. More complex PDFs with layouts and images might require something like Kompare or DiffMerge.
    Type of comparison: Do you need purely textual comparison, visual layout comparison, or both?
    Advanced features: Do you need options like filtering, reporting, or merging the PDFs?
    Budget: Some tools are free and open-source, while others are paid commercial options
o PDF::API2: - Create, modify, and examine PDF files - https://metacpan.org/dist/PDF-API2 - See PDF::API2::Resource::XObject::Image::Imager for important comments about PDF::API2 o PDF::API2::Resource::XObject::Image::Imager: - Import Imager images into PDF - https://metacpan.org/dist/PDF-API2-Resource-XObject-Image-Imager o PDF::Builder: - Facilitates the creation and modification of PDF files - https://github.polettix.it/ETOOBUSY/2022/11/07/a-pdf-workaround/ - Use PDF::Builder via JSON config: https://codeberg.org/polettix/pdfunnel - See also https://www.catskilltech.com/FreeSW/product/PDF%2DBuilder/title/PDF%3A%3ABuilder/freeSW_full - Example code: https://www.catskilltech.com/Examples/PDF/Builder.html o PDF::Collage: - Layer stuff, e.g. SVG images, over PDFs - https://github.polettix.it/ETOOBUSY/2023/05/09/svg-text-elements/ o PDF::Data: - Manipulate PDF files and objects as data structures - Can read and write in OO style - https://metacpan.org/dist/PDF-Data - Ships with utility pdf_data for dumping stuff - For a huge amount of info, see email from Deven T. Corzine, Friday 13:22 2024-09-27 o PDF::FromHTML: - Convert HTML documents to PDF - https://metacpan.org/dist/PDF-FromHTML o PDF other: - Mojo::PDF - Mxpress::PDF - PDF::Cairo - PDF::Create - PDF::CreateSimple - PDF::EasyPDF - PDF::Haru - PDF::Report wraps PDF::API2 o PDF::Reuse: - Reuse and mass produce PDF documents - https://metacpan.org/dist/PDF-Reuse - This module has an important See Also o PDF::Table: - A utility class for building table layouts in a PDF::Builder (or PDF::API2) object - See also https://www.catskilltech.com/FreeSW/product/PDF%2DTable/title/PDF%3A%3ATable/freeSW_full - Example code: https://www.catskilltech.com/Examples/PDF/Table.html o PDF::WebKit: - Use WebKit to Generate PDFs from HTML (via wkhtmltopdf) - https://metacpan.org/dist/PDF-WebKit o PDFio::Architect: - Creating and manipulating PDF files - https://metacpan.org/dist/PDFio-Architect o PDFio::FFI: - Perl FFI bindings for the PDFio C library - https://metacpan.org/pod/PDFio::FFI - It allows you to read, write, and manipulate PDF files from Perl by exposing the PDFio API o Poppler: - https://metacpan.org/pod/Poppler - Bindings to the poppler PDF rendering library - http://poppler.freedesktop.org - Could not install this under Debian bookworm even after using: - cpanm ExtUtils::PkgConfig and - sudo apt-get install libpoppler-glib-dev and - sudo apt-get install gobject-introspection and - PKG_CONFIG_PATH=/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu and - PKG_CONFIG_PATH=/usr/share and - cpanm Glib::Object::Introspection The latter fails with - Package gobject-introspection-1.0 was not found in the pkg-config search path - Sigh - But see PkgConfig - Pure-Perl Core-Only replacement for pkg-config o SVGPDF: - Create PDF XObject from SVG data - https://metacpan.org/pod/SVGPDF - This module processes SVG data and produces one or more PDF XObjects to be placed in a PDF document. This module is intended to be used with PDF::Builder, PDF::API2 and compatible PDF packages o Tools: - https://tools.pdf24.org/en/ - This website offers a huge array of free online PDF tools

o Link to draft guidelines for a security policy for Perl module authors:

o Authen::SASL:
- SASL Authentication framework
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Authen::SASL

o CAPE::Utils:
- A helpful library for CAPE, a MS Windows open-source malware sandbox
- https://metacpan.org/pod/CAPE::Utils
- https://capev2.readthedocs.io/en/latest/introduction/what.html

o CPANSA::DB:
- The CPAN Security Advisory data as a Perl data structure, mostly for CPAN::Audit
- https://metacpan.org/dist/CPANSA-DB

o CSAF:
- Common Security Advisory Framework
- https://metacpan.org/dist/CSAF

o CVE:
- Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures
- https://www.bitsight.com/glossary/common-vulnerabilities-and-exposures-cve
- https://csrc.nist.gov/glossary/term/common_vulnerabilities_and_exposures
- https://www.redhat.com/en/topics/security/what-is-cve
- CPANSec has just been authorized as a CVE Numbering Authority (CNA) for Perl and modules on CPAN (2025-02-26)
- https://security.metacpan.org/2025/02/25/cpansec-is-cna-for-perl-and-cpan.html
- This allows us to issue and manage CVEs for that scope, and to help facilitate coordinated disclosure. If you need a CVE you can request one by emailing:
- cve-request@security.metacpan.org.
- If a third-party requests a CVE we will ensure that they have reached out to perl-security (or the CPAN author) first and facilitate a discussion if necessary

The CVE.org CNA record also provides the email address to request a CVE
number.

https://www.cve.org/PartnerInformation/ListofPartners/partner/CPANSec

Additional details are available in the CNA disclosure policy.

https://security.metacpan.org/docs/cna-disclosure-policy.html

Stig Palmquist (STIGTSP), Timothy Legge (TIMLEGGE) and Breno G. de Oliveira
(GARU) are administering the CNA.  If you are interested in helping or
learning more please contact us at cna@security.metacpan.org.

o CVSS:
- Perl extension for CVSS (Common Vulnerability Scoring System) 2.0/3.x/4.0
- https://metacpan.org/dist/CVSS

https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Prereq - Supersedes the next module o Test::Prereq::Meta: - Test distribution prerequisites against CPAN meta data file - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Prereq-Meta o Test regexps: - test.openssl.pl o Test::Settings: - Ask or tell when certain types of tests should be run - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::Settings o Test::Signature: - Automated SIGNATURE testing - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::Signature - See also Module::Signature in ModuleBuilding o Test::Simple: - Basic utilities for writing tests - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Simple - Has a huge array of components - Contains Test::More and Test2 - But see the next module o Test::Simpler: - Simpler than Test::Simple; more powerful than Test::More - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::Simpler o Test::Smoke: - The Perl core test smoke suite - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Smoke o Test::TempDir::Tiny - Temporary directories that stick around when tests fail - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-TempDir-Tiny - Strongly recommended over File::Temp which uses global "our" variables, which affects Capture::Tiny, since the latter also uses File::Temp. Don't do that o Test::URI: - Check Uniform Resource Identifiers - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-URI o Test::utf8: - Handy utf8 tests - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-utf8 o Test::Warnings: - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Warnings o Test::WWW::Simple: - Test Web applications using TAP - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::WWW::Simple o Test::XML::Simple: - Easy testing for XML - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::XML::Simple o Test::YAFT: - Yet another testing framework - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-YAFT o Test2::Plugin::UUID: - Use REAL UUIDs in Test2 - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test2-Plugin-UUID o Test2::Harness: - Contains yath, which replaces test and prove (see below for usage of prove) - https://metacpan.org/pod/yath. Install via App::Yath - https://perladvent.org/2023/2023-12-23.html o Test2::Require::ProgramInPath: - Skip test unless a program exists in the PATH - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test2-Require-ProgramInPath o Test2::Tools::ComboObject: - Combine checks and diagnostics into a single test as an object - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test2-Tools-ComboObject o Test2::Tools::DOM: - Tools to test HTML/XML-based DOM representations - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test2-Tools-DOM o Test2::Tools::TypeTiny: - Test2 tools for checking Type::Tiny types - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test2-Tools-TypeTiny - o Test2::Transition: - Transition notes when upgrading to Test2 - Contained in: https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Simple/view/lib/Test2/Transition.pod - See also: https://metacpan.org/pod/Test2::Suite o Test2::Util::DistFiles: - Gather files in a distribution - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test2-Util-DistFiles o Test2::V0: - Is becoming very popular - Convert from Test::More to Test2::V0 as described below in the 'pre' tagged section o Overview of conversion from Test::More to Test2::V0: 
Test2 has a "migration guide" manual that you might find useful:

  https://metacpan.org/pod/Test2::Manual::Testing::Migrating

Though honestly I find I get my tests about 99% correct already by
simply doing:

  $ find -name \*.t | xargs sed -i 's/use Test::More/use Test2::V0/'
  $ find -name \*.t | xargs sed -i 's/is_deeply(/is(/'

then manually editing any other edge-cases that I find; but that's
perhaps easier because my existing test style already mostly matched
what Test2 wanted.

I gave this a bash in a codebase I help maintain, and it worked well
enough, save for the fact that we use(d) the "tests => "
syntax, so I had to get rid of that and add "done_testing" to the end of
all the tests. I never enjoyed counting and updating the number of tests
anyway, so I consider this an improvement :-)

FWIW, the replacement of this is a subsequent call to plan($num); but
done_testing is certainly more commonly used as maintenance of the plan
tends to be more trouble than it's worth.

- Features:

- Automatically extracts sentiments (positivity/negativity), opinion objects (e.g., product features with associated sentiment phrases) and emotions (liking, anger, disgust, etc.) in unstructured text data
- Identifies elements in text and classifies them into predefined categories such as personal names, names of organizations, position/occupation, nationality, geographical location, date, age, duration and names of events
- Automatically generates a summary (short description) of a document with its main ideas
- With Related Facts automatically generates a summary (short description) from multiple documents with their main ideas
- Accurately compares documents of any format and determines the degree of similarity between them

""" o See also: - https://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax - Syntax reference

o Escape character for '/' is '#&47;'. See also /''''/ and '////'. Click edit (pencil) to examine

o Care! TiddlyWikis contains executable code in order to provide all the features listed below:
- Your download or antivirus software might complain

o Overview:
- Each TiddlyWiki is restricted to a single web page
- Each page must use named paragraphs
- The purpose of these restrictions is to impose guidelines for the naming of things
- These guidelines help people with no expertise in data collation to index items carefully
- So, they help prevent growth-like-topsy, a major problem will old-style wikis
- Do yourself a favour and always include a para in every TiddlyWiki called MainMenu (or Index or TableOfContents), and put in it an alphabetical list of para names

o Inbuilt features of all TiddlyWikis:
- Search engine
- Editor (can be sent commands, and can generate HTML)
- The 3 double-quotes at the top of this para is one such command, but they are only visible when you click the pencil (edit) icon to enter edit mode for a para
- Encryption (good for passwords)
- History of paras edited per day
- Import capability (a way of sharing)
- Programmable in that you can list what paras are to be opened automatically when the file is loaded into the web client (browser). Hence the para called GettingStarted

o On-line help:
- See tiddlywiki.com for a free download and many add-ons from the eco-system
- The homepage is a TiddlyWiki, and you really should read the para GettingStarted
- It is quite different than my GettingStarted para
- In the eco-system there are various public hosting options giving other ways to share besides the import feature mentioned above
title: TiddlyWikis

- See also:

The Unicode Standard is more than characters and properties.
- perluniprops
- unichars from Unicode-Tussle (e.g. unichars '\p{Hiragana}')
- See also charnames
- Sample usage:
use strict;
use warnings;
use feature      qw( say );
use experimental qw( regex_sets );

use utf8;                              # Source encoded using UTF-8.
use open ":std", ":encoding(UTF-8)";   # Terminal provides/expects UTF-8.

use charnames qw( :full );
use Encode    qw( decode_utf8 );

@ARGV == 1
   or die("usage\n");

my $s = decode_utf8($ARGV[0]);

for my $cp ( unpack "W*", $s ) {
   my $ch = chr($cp);
   if ( $ch =~ /(?[ \p{Print} - \p{Mark} ])/ ) {   # Not sure if good enough.
      printf "â€¹%sâ€º ", $ch;
   } else {
      print "--- ";
   }

   printf "U+%X ", $cp;

   say charnames::viacode($cp);
}

text:
""" o Archive::7zip: - Read/write 7z, zip, ISO9960 and other archives - https://metacpan.org/dist/Archive-SevenZip o Archive::Libarchive::Compress: - Recursively archive a directory (using libarchive) - https://metacpan.org/dist/Archive-Libarchive-Compress - Contains many modules o Archive::Libarchive::Peek: - Peek into archives without extracting them - https://metacpan.org/dist/Archive-Libarchive-Peek o Archive::SCS: - SCS archive controller - https://metacpan.org/pod/Archive::SCS o Archive::Tar::Wrapper: - API wrapper around the 'tar' utility - https://metacpan.org/pod/Archive::Tar::Wrapper - This module differs from Archive::Tar in 2 ways o Archive::Unzip::Burst: - Featureless but fast ZIP extraction - https://metacpan.org/pod/Archive::Unzip::Burst o Archive::Zip: - Provide an interface to ZIP archive files - https://metacpan.org/pod/Archive::Zip o Archive::Zip::SimpleZip: - Create Zip Archives - Package contains Archive::Zip::SimpleUnzip - https://metacpan.org/pod/Archive::Zip::SimpleZip - Supports deflate, store, bzip2, Zstandard (Zstd), Xz and lzma compression o Archive::Zip::SimpleUnzip: - Read Zip Archives - https://metacpan.org/pod/Archive::Zip::SimpleUnzip - Supports deflate, store, bzip2, Zstandard (Zstd), Xz and lzma compression o App::zipdetails: - Display the internal structure of zip files - https://metacpan.org/dist/App-zipdetails - The zipinfo program that comes with the info-zip distribution (http://www.info-zip.org/) can also display details of the structure of a zip file o Compress::Zstd: - Perl interface to the Zstd (Zstandard) (de)compressor - No dictionary support but support ticket has sample code - https://metacpan.org/pod/Compress::Zstd o Compression::Util: - Implementation of various techniques used in data compression - https://metacpan.org/dist/Compression-Util - Contains
* Burrows-Wheeler transform
* Move-to-front transform
* Huffman Coding
* Arithmetic Coding (in fixed bits)
* Run-length encoding
* Fibonacci coding
* Elias gamma/omega coding
* Delta coding
* BWT-based (de)compression
* LZ77/LZSS (de)compression
* LZW (de)compression
* Bzip2 (de)compression
* GZIP (de)compression
* ZLIB (de)compression
* LZ4 (de)compression
o File::Unpack2: - A strong bz2/gz/zip/tar/cpio/rpm/deb/cab/lzma/7z/rar/... archive unpacker, based on mime-types o FU::Utils - Miscellaneous Utility Functions - https://metacpan.org/pod/FU::Util - Supports booleans, brotli, file descriptor passing, gzip, HTTP dates and json o Gzip::Faster: - Simple and fast gzip and gunzip - https://metacpan.org/dist/Gzip-Faster o Gzip::Libdeflate: - Libdeflate compression library - This module provides an interface to libdeflate. Libdeflate is a newly-written compression library which offers the same deflate form of compression as zlib, as used in gzip, libpng and many similar utilities. This distribution includes libdeflate within itself, so it is not necessary to have that on your system o Gzip::RandomAccess: - Extract arbitrary bits of a gzip stream - https://metacpan.org/pod/Gzip::RandomAccess o IO::Compress: - Is an interface to zlib compression library - https://metacpan.org/dist/IO-Compress/view/lib/IO/Compress/FAQ.pod - Contains streamzip to create a zip file from stdin - Contains zipdetails to display the internal structure of zip files o IO::Compress::Brotli: - Write Brotli buffers/streams - https://metacpan.org/pod/IO::Compress::Brotli o IO::Compress::Zip: - Write zip files/buffers - https://metacpan.org/pod/IO::Compress::Zip - Supports store, deflate, bzip2, lzma, xz, zstd o IO::Uncompress::Unzip: - Read zip files/buffers - https://metacpan.org/pod/IO::Uncompress::Unzip o streamzip: - Create a zip file from stdin - https://metacpan.org/pod/streamzip - Supports store, deflate, bzip2, lzma, xz, zstd o XS::libbrotli: - Brotli compression library for XS. - https://metacpan.org/pod/XS::libbrotli
title: ZipFiles
